These remaining findings under this clause are specific to the Portable Vacuum Cooling Trailer / Tubes known as 'Tubes'. 

These Tubes are considered by the Monterey County as an integral part of the Fresh Express West PSM. However, the 'ownership' and control of these systems are not controlled by Fresh Express West but reside with BC Systems.

Maintenance and MOC is not managed or controlled by Fresh Express West. It is unknown what, if any, controls are in place to manage these units. 

Fresh Express West is considered by the county of Monterey to have the 'Tubes' controlled under their PSM. However, Fresh Express West has no visibility or control over these systems. This represents a significant risk to the Chiquita/Fresh Express corporation at this location.	The mobile systems Portable Vacuum Cooling Trailer / Tubes should be incorporated into the MOC and maintenance controls of Fresh Express West as they are considered by Monterey County as an integral part of the Fresh Express West PSM	Completed - This is no longer applicable.  As of September 2014, the portable refrigeration units are no longer used.

6.	Emergency Response Program
Fresh Express has developed and implemented multiple emergency response programs to provide guidance during various types of emergency events, including medical emergencies.  These programs were most recently updated in September 2012.  Part of the established emergency response programs is the formation of a Plant Emergency Organization.  This team works with the onsite incident commander and emergency response coordinator to handle emergencies in an organized manner.  All team members are trained annually in emergency response activities.  Notification of emergency events is provided through an audible alarm system.  Fresh Express employees participate in an annual evacuation drill to ensure they are familiar with the emergency procedures.
Specific Ammonia Release Reporting Guidelines have been developed to ensure adequate preparedness and appropriate response to ammonia releases.  These guidelines were updated in September 2014 and describe outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, evacuation procedures and response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases.  All refrigeration personnel

nia water out.  The room was evacuated due to ammonia levels.  The total release was calculated at 0.621938 pounds.
¿	December 18, 2012:  An ammonia smell was detected on the roof near zone 4 coil 2.  The smell was due to a worn out gasket.  The valve was isolated and repaired.  Minimal vapor was lost.
¿	March 1, 2014:  An ammonia odor smell was reported on the fruit side of the plant.  The area was evacuated and refrigeration personnel were contacted.  They investigated the situation and found that the odor was coming from the water on line 84.  Ammonia levels reached 6ppm.  There was a small leak from the plate and frame chiller which caused ammonia to be released into the water.  The chiller was isolated and pumped down.  The chiller is off line until an ammonia sensor is installed on the water side of the plate and frame.  The total release was calculated at 0.12 pounds.
¿	October 21, 2014 - An ammonia smell was reported around 1:20AM.  The area was evacuated except for refrigeration personnel.  The personnel who reported the smell reported having a headache and feeling nauseous and were examined and sent home for the day.  All units were checked and no leak was found.  The roof was checked and a leak was found coming from the liquid feed solenoid valve.  The smell was getting into the room through a conduit pipe that goes through the sealing to the shaker room.  The liquid line was isolated and the solenoid valve and strainers where replaced.  The incident lasted roughly 3 hours.  The total release was calculated at 18.9 pounds.  The local CUPA was called at 2:32AM.
¿	October 31, 2014 - An ammonia smell was reported around 4:05AM.  All units were checked and no leak was found.  The roof was checked and no leak was found.  Hot gassed all the coils in the shaker room starting with the ones located at the corner that the smell was reported.  While hot gassing Z2C13 found the leak on a rusted pipe in the heather for the coil.  The unit was immediately isolated,

5.	Prevention Program Information
a)	The ammonia refrigeration system at Fresh Express is a Program Level 3 Process.  The information below applies to all components of the ammonia refrigeration system at Fresh Express' Salinas facility.
b)	The SIC code for the process is 2099 (NAICS 311991).
c)	The chemical covered is anhydrous ammonia.
d)	The date of the most recent review or revision of the safety information was August 2014 and this review was conducted per the process hazard analysis requirements.  Previous process hazard analysis information along with the latest mechanical integrity information was reviewed.
e)	The date of the most recent hazard review or update was August 21, 2014.  The technique used was a What-If Analysis.
o	The expected completion date of issues identified in the PHA is December 2015

re Receivers were chosen.  Since the High Pressure Receivers cannot operate above 80% of maximum capacity, 20,122 pounds was used as the worst-case release amount.
Pursuant to the Environmental Protection Agency / Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Office's (EPA/CEPPO's) Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, the meteorological and site specific variables assumed for the analysis are as follows:
Worst-Case Release Scenario Assumptions
Chemical Name:	Anhydrous Ammonia
Physical State:	Pressurized Liquid
Basis of Results:	RMP*Comp V 1.07
Scenario:	Liquid spill vaporizes to airborne vapor and droplets
Quantity Released, lbs:	20,122 lbs
Release Rate:	2,012 lbs/min
Release Duration:	10 minutes
Wind Speed:	1.5 meters per second
Atmospheric Stability Class:	F
Topography (Surface Roughness)	Rural
Toxic Endpoint Concentration:	0.14 mg/L (ERPG-2)
Distance to Endpoint, mi:	2.2 mi 
Receptors:	See Section 3.6
Vessel or System Considered:	Dual High-Pressure Receivers
Vessel Location:	Outdoors
Passive Mitigation Considered:	None
Active Mitigation Considered:	None
Total Population within distance to endpoint:	See Section 3.6
Release Rate - Ammonia is a liquid under pressure in this part of the refrigeration system.  The guidance specifies the release rate as the quantity released as a gas over 10 minutes.  This rapid release of ammonia is an airborne mixture of vapor and droplets.  Since the High Pressure Receiver (HPR) is located outdoors, all the vapor and droplets are assumed to remain airborne.  The release rate is calculated as follows:
QR = Q/10
Where: 	QR = Release Rate (lbs/min)
		   Q = Quantity Released (lbs)
Using our scenario criteria:
QR = 20,122 lbs/10 min = 2,012 lbs/min (unmitigated)
Distance to the Toxic Endpoint - Based on the estimated worst-case release rate of 2,012lbs/min, RMP*Comp V 1.07 shows the distance to the toxic endpoint at 2.2 miles from the dual High Pressure Receivers.  The rural distance

was used, since there are no buildings in the immediate area.
Alternative Release Scenario Analysis
Pursuant to RMP and Cal-ARP regulations, the alternative release scenario was identified as that which is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario, and that which will reach an endpoint offsite.  The alternative release scenario used meteorological conditions more representative of the site than those used for the worst case.  
The alternate-case scenario involves a vapor release of 343 lbs of ammonia from a ruptured process line.  In this scenario, the line has ruptured due to thermal expansion of liquid ammonia that is trapped between two valves (referred to as double blocking).  The largest volume section of piping that could be double-blocked is a 2-inch nominal inside diameter tie-in line to the evaporators, which is 394 feet in length and located on the roof of the Main Process Building. 
The alternative release scenario variables and assumptions are therefore as follows:
Alternative Release Scenario Assumptions
Chemical Name:	Anhydrous Ammonia
Physical State:	Vapor
Basis of Results:	RMP*Comp V 1.07
Scenario:	Double Blocked Liquid Piping (394 ft length, 2-inch nominal inside diameter)
Quantity Released, lbs:	343 lbs
Release Rate:	114 lbs/min
Release Duration:	3 minutes
Wind Speed:	3 meters per second
Atmospheric Stability Class:	D
Topography (Surface Roughness):	Rural
Toxic Endpoint Concentration:	0.14 mg/L (Appendix A, 40 CFR 68)
Distance to Endpoint, mi:	0.2 mi
Receptors:	See Section 3.6
System Considered:	Tie-In Line to Evaporators, roof of Main Process Building. 130 psig.
Vessel Location:	Outdoors
Passive Mitigation Considered:	None
Active Mitigation Considered:	None
Total population within distance to endpoint:	See Section 3.6

2.	Registration Information
Registration information for this Risk Management Plan is as follows:

b)	The Dun and Bradstreet number is 15-448-3457
c)	Chiquita Brands International is the corporate p

l areas and major commercial or industrial areas.  Based on review of the MARPLOT program data and Google Earth within the worst-case release radius, there are 11,756 residences, 44 churches, 18 schools, 14 parks, 13 shopping centers, 10 daycares, 10 waterways (ditches, creeks, sloughs and rivers), 4 health care facilities, 3 hospitals and 1 airport. Within the alternative release scenario radius, there are 4 residences and 1 school.
Environmental Receptors
Environmental receptors that must be noted in the RMP are natural areas, such as national or state parks, forests or monuments, wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges or areas and Federal wilderness areas.  In the worst-case release radius, there are ten waterways (ditches, creeks, sloughs and rivers).  In the alternate-case release radius, there is one slough.

 

 
 
4.	Five Year Accident History
Between 2009 and the present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. However, the following ammonia-related incidents occurred:
¿	January 27, 2010:  There was a leak on the electric solenoid valve stem where the stem body had split or cracked due to normal wear.  This resulted in an odor event inside the plant.  The solenoid valve was replaced and the unit was placed back into service.  PM procedures have been updated to ensure solenoid is inspected.
¿	September 27, 2011:  An ammonia smell was detected at the fruit raw product outside door.  The smell was due to pin-hole leak coming out of an evaporator valve station (Z4C19) located on the roof.  The coil was shut down and repaired.  Minimal vapor was lost. 
¿	November 4, 2011:  The drain level of the secondary containment for the purge tank waste water was raised by three feet.  In doing so, this interfered with the flow of the drain water.  This caused the purger bubbler to back-up and the top of the bubbler came off spilling some ammo

inch nominal inside diameter (D) piping, the following calculation was used to determine Q in pounds:
Q = (A)(Lp)(ρ)
Where:	A = cross sectional area of piping, ft2 = (π x D2/4)/(144 ft2/in2)
		Lp = length of piping between blocked valves, ft
		ρ = density of anhydrous ammonia at scenario conditions, lb/ft3
Using our scenario criteria:
A = (π x 22/4)/(144) = 0.0218 ft2
Q = (0.0218 ft2) x (394 feet) x (39.9 lb/ft3) = 343 lbs
The release rate (QR) is dependent on the  of the pipe rupture and the piping pressure, and is calculated pursuant to the guidance document as follows:
QR = HA x 203 x (Pg)½
Where:	HA = Hole Area, in2 = (π x d2/4) [d is the hole diameter]
		Pg = pressure of ammonia, psig
Using our scenario criteria, and assuming that there is a ¼-inch hole in the piping at the point of rupture:
QR = (π x [0.25]2/4) x 203 x (130)½ = 114 lbs/min (unmitigated)
This means that the entire contents (343 lbs) releases in approximately three minutes.
Distance to the Toxic Endpoint - Based on the estimated alternative scenario release rate of 114 lbs/min, Exhibit 4-5 from the guidance shows the distance to the toxic endpoint at 0.2 miles from the ruptured line (the rural distance was used, since there are no buildings in the immediate area).

3.6.	Offsite Impacts
As required by the regulations, Fresh Express has estimated the populations that fall within the circle defined by the distance to toxic endpoints for both the worst-case and alternative release scenarios.
Residential Populations
MARPLOT was used to estimate the population within the worst-case and alternate-case radii.  Using this, it was determined by the Block Group Proration method that approximately 37,173 people (11,756 households) reside within the 2.2-mile radius of the worst-case release scenario.  Approximately 7 people (4 households) reside within the 0.2-mile radius of the alternative release scenario.
A Google Earth map depicting the worst-case and alternative release vapor cloud radii is included in 3.5.
Other Public Receptors
In addition to residences, public receptors that must be noted in the RMP are schools, hospitals, long-term health care and child day care facilities, prisons, public recreationa

he facility, where they are washed, processed, dried, packaged and stored for shipment. 
A stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is used for room cooling and process water chilling.  The total anhydrous ammonia charge to the system is 57,482 pounds.
The site is located southwest of Spreckles Junction near the intersection of Abbott Street and East Blanco Road in Salinas.  Residential, commercial and industrial areas are located north of the Fresh Express facility with a large rural area directly south.  The Union Pacific Railroad is located east of the Fresh Express property.
The site includes a large Main Processing Building connected to a small Administration Building, the Refrigeration Engine Room, small support buildings, the shipping and receiving areas and employee and visitor parking lots. Some refrigeration equipment and piping are located outdoors.  A site plan is presented below in Figure 3-1.
 
Figure 3-1 Site Plan
 
3.2.	OCA Methodology
The analyses herein follow the requirements specified by both the Federal RMP (40 CFR 68.22) and Cal-ARP (19 CCR 2750.2).  The method follows Chapter 4 of the EPA/CEPPO Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration dated May 2000. Google Earth software application was used to map the offsite consequence analysis (OCA) for the Worst-Case and Alternative Release scenarios. In addition, MARPLOT was used for population information.
3.3.	Release Scenarios
Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis
Since the Fresh Express ammonia refrigeration system is considered an RMP/Cal-ARP Program 3 process, the worst-case release scenario was identified as that which was estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to the toxic endpoint for ammonia.  The worst-case release quantity was defined as the greatest amount potentially held in a single vessel location, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity.  With a maximum capacity of 25,153 pounds, the High Pressu

m are made.  All changes to the refrigeration system must go through the same channel thus ensuring modifications are tracked and appropriate documents updated.

Fresh Express Refrigeration Management Organizational Chart

 

 
1.	Executive Summary
1.1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The management at Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Utility & Facility Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The site has specific written evacuation, reporting and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public and the environment in the event of an ammonia release.  This is a non-responding facility thus external emergency response personnel will be called in to assist with any major releases or injuries.  Additionally this site has written procedures regarding the safe and proper use of hazardous materials.
1.2.	Stationary Sources and Regulated Substance
The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 900 E. Blanco Road in Salinas, California.  The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage and transported and distributed from this site.
The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia which is used to refrigerate produce at various temperatures.  The ammonia refrigeration system consists of a stationary system with an ammonia charge of 57,482 lbs.
1.3.	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  
This includes:
¿	Compliance with industry standards and codes

in effect at the time of initial construction and modification
¿	Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information
¿	Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by refrigeration personnel
¿	Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel
¿	Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs
¿	Application of established auditing, inspection and pre-start-up review protocols
¿	Use of qualified contractors for work on the system
The ammonia refrigeration system has numerous engineering and administrative controls in place to ensure safe operation of the system and to help reduce the potential of an accidental release.  Additionally, Ammonia Release Reporting Guidelines have been developed to provide detailed steps regarding reporting and responding to ammonia releases (see Section 6).
1.4.	Five Year Accident History
Between 2009 and present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths or property damage or off-site environmental damage, evacuations or shelter in place.  However, there were seven minor ammonia-related incidents which occurred between 2009 and 2014.  These incidents are detailed in Section 4.
1.5.	Emergency Response Program
Fresh Express has developed and implemented multiple emergency response programs to provide guidance during various types of emergency events.  Part of the established emergency response programs is the formation of a Plant Emergency Organization.  This team works with the onsite incident commander and emergency response coordinator to handle emergencies in an organized manner.  All team members are trained in emergency response activities.  Notification of emergency events is provided through an audible alarm system.  Spe

Introduction
Environmental Compliance, Health and Occupational Safety (ECHOS) conducted the five year review of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Process Safety Management (PSM) program for the ammonia refrigeration system at the Fresh Express facility located at 900 E. Blanco Road in Salinas, California. This revision was started in July 2014 and completed in December 2014.  The original RMP/PSM was conducted in 1999 by EORM and the last three year compliance audit was conducted in 2012 by S. Creighton Consulting.
This combined Program Level 3 RMP/PSM program was developed and submitted to comply with the following requirements:
¿	California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal-ARP) Program pursuant to 19 CCR 2735 - 2785.1
¿	California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal-OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements pursuant to 8 CCR 5189




 
RMP Management System
Management's commitment to process safety is a critical element of any Risk Management Plan and Process Safety Management program.  The RMP/PSM program is a living document and requires constant implantation and updates.  To ensure these updates are made and the requirements of this program are implemented, Fresh Express has developed a management system to support the RMP/PSM program.  The Utility & Facility Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation and integration of all elements of the RMP/PSM program.  This position has direct supervisory responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  In addition to managing onsite refrigeration personnel, the Utility & Facility Manager also coordinates with outside vendors such as Axiom Engineering, BC Systems, KIE Engineering, Arts Academy, etc. as needed to maintain the requirements of the RMP/PSM program. 3.	Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA)
The OCA for the system was updated in September 2014 as part of the five year review process.
3.1.	Facility Description and Site Layout
The Fresh Express facility located at 900 East Blanco Road in Salinas, California (latitude 36°39'06.23N; longitude 121°38'11.76W) prepares and packages salads and fruits.  Various types of fruits and vegetables are delivered to t

cific Ammonia Release Reporting Guidelines have been developed to ensure adequate preparedness and appropriate response to ammonia releases.  These guidelines describe outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, evacuation procedures and response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases.  This is a non-responding facility thus external emergency response personnel will be called in to assist with any major releases or injuries.  All refrigeration personnel are trained in responding to ammonia releases.
1.6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Numerous updates, modifications and improvements have been made and continue to be made to the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure its continued safe operation.  The tables below summarize the findings and current status of the items identified during the 3-year compliance audit conducted in 2012 and the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) conducted in August 2014

15	The date of last update was 2009, numerous SOPs need review, editing and updates. 

Start-up SOPs do not discriminate whether they are 'Initial' or for use after 'Emergency or Turnaround Shutdowns'. 

There is no 'Temporary usage' at this location. No SOP required.

System capacity calculations are carried out in response to problems rather than routinely. This is a reactive approach.

Water contamination of the system though leaks, damage or maintenance (especially in the chiller areas) is not addressed in SOPs. This can impact the efficiency of the system and cause failures due to corrosion.

SOPs do not address how to manage leaks of ammonia into the produce handling water stream.	Review, edit and update any required procedures, and / or remove outdated ones.

Develop start-up SOPs specific to the stage of equipment usage - Initial start-up, routine maintenance, after emergency shutdown.

Consider a routine capacity validation. 

Develop an SOP to address water ingress into the system. If needed, consider use of suitable water purge technology to maintain quality of ammonia system.

Develop an SOP to address the potential leakage of ammonia into produce handling water stream	Completed - All procedures were reviewed and updated in 2014 as part of the 5 year certification.

SOPs have been updated to include stage specific details. A list of all SOPs is maintained in the PSM/RMP documentation.

The ammonia capacity was validated in 2014.

An SOP has been developed to address water ingress into the system. A list of all SOPs is maintained in the PSM/RMP documentation.

An SOP has been developed to address potential leakage of ammonia into the produce handling water system.  A list of all SOPs is maintained

ed whenever changes to the ammonia refrigeration system occur which affect the procedures or annually, whichever occurs first.  Operating procedures are in place for initial startup, routine operation and maintenance, shutdown and after emergency shutdown. Each procedure contains steps for each applicable operating phase, lists operating limits and hazard consequences of deviation where they are applicable.  A list of operating procedures are maintained in the Prevention Program documentation and actual procedures can be found in the SOP binders located in the engine room and maintenance office conference room.

Maintenance procedures are updated whenever changes to the ammonia refrigeration system occur that affect the procedures or annually, whichever occurs first.  Fresh Express has developed customized maintenance procedures for certain equipment while the manufacturers' recommended maintenance procedures are used for other equipment.  A list of maintenance procedures are maintained in the Prevention Program documentation and actual procedures can be found in the PM binders located in the engine room and maintenance office conference room.
